course.subject: PPOL
course.name: Science, Technology and Society in China
course.description: This course aims to cultivate students’ systematic and critical thinking about science, technology, innovation, and society, especially in light of the transition from traditional China to contemporary China. Differing from the usual courses focusing on this subject, this course will take a social and critical approach, enabling students to understand and analyze the social, political, and cultural preconditions and impacts of scientific and technological development. By the end of the course, students should understand the significance of the social, cultural, and political preconditions underlying scientific and technological innovations and be able to gauge the impact of those innovations. They should also be able to systematically analyze the factors that make innovation significant and use this analysis to critically examine the development of science and technology over the course of China’s history.

reviews.author: SchrodingersCat
reviews.title: Interactive Blended Learning Course Done Right
reviews.comment_content: The course consisted of 4 online modules which included lecture videos, slides and quizzes. After the completion of these 4 modules, the professor gave in-person lectures to wrap up the course. When the online modules are ongoing, one class per week is dedicated as a 'tutorial', wherein you are expected to apply what you have learnt from the modules to case studies that the TAs will introduce and discuss.
reviews.comment_teaching:
For most of the course, the professor was not in lessons and we would only see him in the online modules. During that time, TAs Cassy and Elizabeth would conduct our tutorials. They were exceptional; they conducted the classes with a certain level of enthusiasm that rubbed off on the students. I would say that one of the plus points of the course was the TAs.

Towards the end of the course, Professor Sharif conducted in-person lectures. I can confidently say he is one of the best educators I have ever encountered. His way of teaching and presenting ensures you're always attentive and intrigued, and you definitely will not get bored in his lessons.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class Participation- 20%
Written Assignments- 40%
Quizzes - 20%
Group Presentation- 20%

In person class participation (i.e., contributing to class discussions, asking questions, building upon other's views, etc during tutorials) counts for 10% of the participation grade.

Online participation (i.e. writing short paragraphs of about 200 words answering questions asked by the TAs on canvas) counts for another 10% of the participation grade

There are 4 essays of about 800 words and 10% of the grade each.

There are 4 module quizzes which each contribute 5% of the grade.

The group presentation which occurs towards the end of the semester in the presence of Professor Sharif accounts for 20% of the grade. Every person in your group will receive the same grade.

Grading (in my view) was completely fair and as long as you put in an appropriate amount of effort you will get an A-range.
reviews.comment_workload:
Given that there are no exams for this course, grading falls entirely on the work you do throughout the semester, so you will tend to be a little more thorough with your work during the semester.

While overall the workload was quite manageable, there may be times when there is a lot to do because of the number of online lectures to watch, and the fact that an essay is due every 2 weeks.

reviews.author: wooyoungk
reviews.title: Best TAs and professor
reviews.comment_content: The course materials are attached. Mandatory lecture slides and recorded lectures to complete the quizzes and essays. Offline lectures begin only after Module 4, towards the semester's end. In our weekly tutorials, we discuss course content and connect it to real-world examples.
reviews.comment_teaching: The TAs, Cassy and Elizaveta, are notably exceptional in leading the tutorials in an enjoyable environment to learn. Even beyond the tutorials, they are willing to assist you navigate the course and give detailed guidance on essays and lecture contents. They are also willing to offer you guidance regarding your career path and academics in addition to the course! The professor, whom we met only towards the close of the course, is truly exceptional. His stimulating and thought-provoking lectures make him one of the finest professors I've had the pleasure of learning from.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading in this course is very generous. Despite scoring significantly below average in the first two quizzes, with guidance from the TAs, and help from my classmates in studying for the quizzes and essays, I managed to secure an A range.
reviews.comment_workload:
4 essays of approximately 800 words each (40%)
4 canvas quizzes (20%)
5 discussion posts on Canvas, around 150 words each (10%)
Group presentation (20%)
Class attendance (10%)

reviews.author: crycrycry
reviews.comment_content: We need to watch the ppt (which is mainly about the definition of science, technology, and innovation and China history, development, and innovation)and the video ourselves to finish the quiz, the essay, and the discussion questions(a total of 4). The lectures are only for discussions that are not quite related to the essay and the quiz. The good news is only one lecture for each week and close book exam.
reviews.comment_teaching: The TAs is quite helping and they would like to answer your questions in and off lectures, especially about the essay. Quite upset to get low marks in attendance when attending all the classes and sharing ideas once in almost every lesson.
reviews.comment_grading:
8-9 for each essay(need to do lots of research)
3-4 for short online quizzes (very difficult to get full marks)
get full marks on discussion questions as long as you reply on time and reach the word requirement
13.5/20 in the project which is really low compared to the mean of 15 since our focus is not accurate
The last thing I am really unsatisfactory with is attendance. I attended every class and raise my hand once in almost every lecture. I just get 4/10 which is totally unreasonable(appealing right now hopefully successful).
final grade: B
reviews.comment_workload:
4 essays(each 800 words)(40%)
4 short online quizzes(difficult to get full marks)(20%)
5 discussion questions(100-150 words)(10%)
1 project(20%)
attendance(10%)
*need to watch videos and ppts ourselves

reviews.author: 爛grade人士
reviews.title: Workload大到不了但個grade穩陣
reviews.comment_content:
自己睇syllabus，完全唔洗計數，冇任何science theory，比較似文科，唔鍾意計數真係一流嘅選擇😂

主要都係講歷史，例如why industrial revolution did not happen to China, science and technological development in China, etc.
reviews.comment_teaching:
個人幾鍾意TA嘅tutorial session，一個禮拜中嘅一堂，discuss不同嘅social issues，係拿participation分嘅大好機會，個TA仲要好有耐性聽你講嘢

Professor基本上唔會同佢有咩交流，個TA係我遇過最有心嘅TA，課後會願意email答你問題，Deadline前（甚至上堂前）會announcement/email提你交功課，超有心，同埋好願意聽你意見咁。
reviews.comment_grading:
Class Participation (20%)
Written Assignments @ 10% x 4 (40%)
Quizzes @ 5% x 4 (20%)
Group Presentation (20%)

最後拿左B+，想拿A-看來真係有啲難🥲，Professor係堂上講左會比"Decent grade"🫠

Class Participation每堂tutorial都有出聲，Written assignment 有交拿到8-9分/10分，Quizzes係3和4分/5分，Group presentation 19/20，可謂B range 係基本，A range就難 Lmao
reviews.comment_workload:
多到Cls，冇Exam就係咁架啦

Written assignment 寫800字，仲要寫4篇...分數相信大家都差唔多，仲多過一篇HUMA嘅時1000文，多過/少過佢比嘅range會扣分

Quizzes有4份，Open-book可以夾朋友一起做，但係就算有friend都好難，內容難到...

仲有discussion questions，TA話100-150字就可以

Group presentation 4個人一組，自己分組，題目係講一種innovation in modern China，講有咩influence 同 factors， present and then Q&A 畀人圍插嘅時間，勁多人爭住問你問題呀🥹

最衰係present時間係3日前先同你講要present，係RANDOM，不過PowerPoint要一早交嘅...

仲有係blended learning mode呀，所以要自己睇N年前嘅Powerpoint recording，係勁多，最多10幾條片每條20幾分鐘，好在一個禮拜有一堂唔洗上

reviews.author: miche11e
reviews.title: Good for writers
reviews.comment_content: Personally, the content was very engaging for me. Active discussions during our tutorials. This course mainly just talks about China's history with how they tried to innovate and create their own Industrial Revolution. Divided into 4 modules, you get to dive deeper into China's failures and successes. This class is kind of like a HUMA class.
reviews.comment_teaching: Loved the mixed mode teaching so there was only one class a week. TA Alvin is amazing, had great discussions during class and kept me engaged.
reviews.comment_grading: I think the grading is pretty good. I was always around mean for my quizzes and got below mean for two essays. But actively participated in class and received 18/20 on presentation. My final grade was an A. I think they definitely value participation a lot in this course.
reviews.comment_workload: We had to learn a new module on our own every ~2 weeks or so. For every module, we had to do an 800 word writing, post on discussion board, and take a quiz. The writing may be difficult for some people as the standards are set quite high. Because I really liked the content, I enjoyed doing the assignments too.
